6-science-earth-space-plate-tectonics.title: Plate Tectonics Baseline Quiz
6-science-earth-space-plate-tectonics.description: Quick pulse-check on prior knowledge of tectonic processes before students dive into investigations.

questions.prompt: Which layer of Earth consists of solid rock plates that move over the asthenosphere?

options.feedback: Tectonic plates are sections of the lithosphere.

questions.explanation: The lithosphere is Earth’s rigid outer shell made of the crust and upper mantle.

questions.prompt: Which evidence best supports the theory that continents were once connected?

options.text: Similar climate zones exist on different continents today.
Identical fossils are found on continents separated by oceans.
options.feedback: Matching fossils across oceans provide strong evidence of continental drift.

questions.explanation: Identical fossils on distant continents indicate those land masses were once connected.

questions.prompt: What is most likely happening at a convergent plate boundary between an oceanic and continental plate?

options.text: New crust is forming as magma rises.
The plates slide past each other without vertical movement.
The oceanic plate subducts beneath the continental plate.
options.feedback: Denser oceanic crust dives beneath continental crust, forming trenches and volcanoes.

options.text: Both plates break apart forming a rift valley.

questions.explanation: Convergent plate boundaries with oceanic-continental interaction typically result in subduction.

6-mathematics-number-operations-ratios-p.title: Ratios & Proportions Warm-Up
6-mathematics-number-operations-ratios-p.description: Baseline check on ratio representations to personalize practice sets.

questions.prompt: The ratio of cats to dogs in a shelter is 3 to 5. Which statement correctly describes this ratio?

options.text: For every 3 cats there are 5 dogs.
options.feedback: Ratios compare quantities in order; 3 cats correspond with 5 dogs.

options.text: There are 8 more dogs than cats.
For every 5 cats there are 3 dogs.
There are 3 cats and 5 dogs total.

questions.explanation: Ratios use the order of numbers to describe relationships.

questions.prompt: A smoothie recipe uses 2 cups of strawberries for every 3 cups of yogurt. How many cups of strawberries are needed with 9 cups of yogurt?

options.feedback: Multiply both parts of the ratio by 3 to maintain the proportion.

questions.explanation: The ratio 2:3 scales to 6:9 when multiplied by 3.

questions.prompt: A car travels 180 miles on 6 gallons of gas. What is the unit rate in miles per gallon?

options.feedback: Compute 180 ÷ 6 to find 30 miles per gallon.

questions.explanation: Divide total miles by gallons (180 ÷ 6) to obtain the 30 mpg unit rate.

9-mathematics-algebra-hs-pathways-linear.title: Algebra I: Linear & Quadratic Foundations
9-mathematics-algebra-hs-pathways-linear.description: Quick baseline to check readiness with slope, intercepts, and basic quadratic features.

questions.prompt: What is the slope of the line y = 1.5x - 4?

options.feedback: In slope-intercept form y = mx + b, m is the slope.

questions.prompt: Which statement is true about the graph of y = -2(x - 3)^2 + 1?

options.text: It opens upward with vertex at (3, 1).
It opens downward with vertex at (3, 1).
options.feedback: The negative leading coefficient flips the parabola down; vertex form shows (h, k) = (3, 1).

options.text: It opens downward with vertex at (-3, 1).
It opens upward with vertex at (-3, -1).

questions.prompt: Solve for the x-intercepts of y = x^2 - 9.

options.feedback: Set x^2 - 9 = 0 and take the square root of 9.

questions.prompt: What is the rate of change for the line through (1, 4) and (4, 13)?
A line models earnings E = 18t + 45, where t is hours worked. What does 45 represent?

options.text: Starting bonus before any hours are worked
options.feedback: The y-intercept is the starting amount when t = 0.

questions.prompt: Which function type fits a data set where first differences are not constant but second differences are constant?

options.feedback: Quadratic sequences have constant second differences.

questions.prompt: Which equation represents the line passing through (0, -2) and (4, 6)?

options.feedback: Slope = 2 and the point (0, -2) gives the intercept.

10-mathematics-algebra-hs-pathways-polyn.title: Polynomial Operations & Identities Check
10-mathematics-algebra-hs-pathways-polyn.description: Baseline pulse on adding, multiplying, factoring polynomials, and interpreting graphs.

questions.prompt: What is the degree of the polynomial -3x^5 + 4x^2 - 7?

options.feedback: The highest exponent is 5.

questions.prompt: Which expression is equivalent to (2x - 3)(x + 1)?

options.feedback: Distribute: 2x*x + 2x*1 -3*x -3*1.

questions.prompt: Factor the polynomial x^2 - 8x + 15.

options.feedback: Numbers -3 and -5 multiply to 15 and add to -8.

questions.prompt: What is the remainder when f(x) = x^3 - 4x + 1 is divided by (x - 2)?

options.feedback: Use the Remainder Theorem: f(2) = 8 - 8 + 1 = 1.

questions.prompt: Where does the graph of y = (x - 2)(x + 1)(x + 4) cross the x-axis?

options.feedback: Each factor gives a zero at its root.

questions.prompt: Which identity is correct?

options.feedback: Square each term and double the product.

questions.prompt: Which end behavior matches f(x) = -x^4 + 6x^2 - 2?

options.text: As x increases in magnitude, f(x) goes to negative infinity.
options.feedback: Even degree with negative leading coefficient falls on both ends.

options.text: As x increases in magnitude, f(x) goes to positive infinity.
It rises to the right and falls to the left.
It has horizontal asymptotes at y = 0.
